awd_titl_txt: EAR-PF: Active Tectonics and Crustal Structure of Northern Alaska
awd_abstract_narration:
Dr. Bryant Chow has been awarded an NSF EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship to investigate the question of why earthquakes occur where they do. This work will take place at the University of Alaska Fairbanks under the mentorship of Dr. Carl Tape. The Earth’s crust is the outermost shell where all human activity takes place. Fractured into many tectonic plates, the crust hosts disastrous events, such as earthquakes, tsunamis, and volcanic eruptions, near its surface. Earthquakes typically occur where two or more plates meet, but they can also occur far from plate boundaries. The processes that cause these earthquakes are not well understood. This project seeks to characterize Earth’s crustal structure, linking deep-Earth processes with surface geological activity to explore why earthquakes occur where they do. The work will investigate plate tectonic processes and crustal structure in northern Alaska, an understudied region far from plate boundaries that has hosted M>4 earthquakes. The goal is to characterize earthquakes and develop high-resolution models of the crust in order to understand how tectonic forces are transferred far into the interior of plates. Although population density in northern Alaska is low, earthquake hazard remains important for infrastructure, environmental, and industrial purposes and is critical for development in the region. Alaska’s North Slope is a major oil producing region for the United States, and northeastern Alaska is home to the largest national wildlife refuge in the country. This project involves outreach to local communities in northern Alaska using novel teaching tools to convey earthquake risks and hazards.  Additionally, Dr. Chow will produce a comprehensive catalog of models that can be used for characterizing earthquake hazard. 

This project proposes a detailed seismotectonic investigation of northern Alaska to constrain mechanisms controlling tectonics in and around the region. Northern Alaska features diffuse seismicity and large-scale deformation far from the plate boundaries. However, the structures and processes involved are not well understood. Due to its remoteness, difficulties in mapping and monitoring of northern Alaska have resulted in historically sparse coverage. This changed following the deployment of the EarthScope Transportable Array in Alaska, with years of high-quality seismic data now available for a comprehensive study. This project involves investigation of two scientific questions: Are deformation and structure in northeastern Alaska consistent with (1) far field deformation from plate convergence 1000 km away? and (2) extrusional extension of western Alaska? This work will advance understanding of how global geodynamic processes shape continental scale tectonics and relate to regional deformation and local seismicity, using waveform cross-correlation techniques and 3D numerical waveform simulations. Detection and re-location of seismicity will be followed by inversion of seismic moment tensors to constrain fault structure and deformation characteristics. Waveform simulations will be used to validate existing tomography models of northern Alaska and for subsequent full-waveform tomography, which will result in high-resolution structural models of the crust and upper mantle. Ambient noise adjoint tomography will provide a velocity model of northern Alaska with resolution on the order of tens of km. A subsequent earthquake adjoint tomography inversion will refine a northeastern subset of this model, resulting in km scale resolutions. The success of these tasks will lead to refined earthquake catalogs, high resolution velocity models, and detailed interpretations of tectonic processes for northern Alaska.

This project is jointly funded by the EAR Postdoctoral Fellowship program, the Established Program to Stimulate Competitive Research (EPSCoR), and the EAR Geophysics program.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

pgm_ref.pgm_ref_txt: EXP PROG TO STIM COMP RES

por.por_cntn:
Northern Alaska features diffuse seismicity and large-scale deformations far from the nearest plate boundary at the Alaska-Aleutian subduction zone. However, the structures and processes involved are not well understood. Due to its remoteness, difficulties in mapping and monitoring of northern Alaska have resulted in historically sparse coverage. Therefore, this project’s main objective was to undertake a detailed seismotectonic investigation of northern Alaska, leveraging a historic deployment of instruments in Alaska, to constrain mechanisms controlling tectonics in and around the region. In this project we aimed to use a sophisticated seismic imaging technique, adjoint tomography, and high performance computers, to create detailed models of Earth structure below northern Alaska. 

In order to undertake this research, I developed a number of open-source software for seismic imaging, hosted under the organizational name 'adjTomo'. Tools hosted under adjTomo include automated workflow tools for high performance computers, and seismic data download, visualization and processing tools. These software were developed with community use in mind, and are provided open-source, alongside documentation and examples to lower the barrier of entry for new users. In order to promote these efforts, I created and hosted a three day virtual workshop for new users of the community seismic simulation software, SPECFEM. This workshop saw up to 200 global participants running SPECFEM, and adjTomo tools, to perform seismic simulations and inversions from the comfort of their own homes.


Using the tools developed in this project, I performed synthetic and real-data inversions for crust and upper mantle structure below northern Alaska using ambient noise cross correlations, a unique dataset of seismic data generated primarily by ocean waves. Synthetic inversions were used to validate the methodology and software, and the ongoing real-data inversions show significant improvements in waveform fits and resolution of velocity structures at depths between the surface of the Earth and roughly 100 km depth. The final velocity model resulting from this work is expected to provide key information on tectonic structures below northern Alaska. Additionally, through the support of this fellowship, I was able to join geologists from the Alaska Division of Geological and Geophysical Surveys for a field mapping project in the northern foothills of the Brooks Range, Alaska. There I gained deep insight into the structure of the Brooks Range and adjacent North Slope, which will be key for understanding computational models of the region.


In addition to research outputs from this project, I have laid foundational groundwork for a number of efforts meant to disseminate the results of this project with the general public. These include an art-science collaboration with a local Alaska artist to co-produce a painting inspired and informed by this research, which will be exhibited in public and academic spaces to spark dialogue related to seismic imaging research, and northern Alaska. Similarly this project has begun work on a number of outreach trips to northern Alaska villages, where I aim to give public science talks to communities and classrooms.

 

This project has laid critical foundational groundwork for understanding complex tectonic structures in Alaska, and hopes to deepen ties between scientists and residents in Alaska. This project's legacy continues through my ongoing research and teaching efforts as an Assistant Professor of Seismology at the University of Alaska Fairbanks.


Last Modified: 12/29/2023
Modified by: Bryant Chow
